Discharge Summary

Patient Name: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:

This patient was admitted with left back pain which had been persistent for over 6 months and had recently aggravated. Radiological examination revealed a cavitary lesion in the left lower lobe of the lung that was indicative of pulmonary chronic inflammation. The lesion was confirmed to be hamartoma after histology revealed the diagnosis. 
Subsequently, a left lower lobectomy was performed. The histopathological analysis of the lung resection specimen indicated the chronic inflammation of the lower left lung tissue with dysplasia glandular ducts and cystic cavities formation. The patient had a smooth recovery period and remained asymptomatic during the 12-months of postoperative follow-up period. 

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with mixed type of CCAM.

Procedures:

1. Core biopsy of the solid components of the lesion
2. Left lower lobectomy 

Condition on Discharge:

The patient was in stable condition on discharge. 

Follow-up:

The patient was provided with appropriate advice regarding follow-up appointments with their physician. 

Thanks for consulting with us.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 38-year old female admitted for routine investigation of non-specific abdominal disturbances.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our clinic for investigation of intermittent episodes of diarrhea lasting for a couple of months. The physical examination was unremarkable except for dilated submucosal veins throughout the colon seen on colonoscopy, which was consistent with extensive colonic varices. The patient underwent several tests including serological markers for liver diseases, abdominal ultrasound, Doppler examination, ARFI elastography, clotting studies, autoantibody profile, immunoglobulins, upper digestive endoscopy, and small bowel series, which were all normal. A selective angiography of inferior mesenteric artery was performed, which showed stasis of the contrast medium within the descendent colon.

Diagnosis:
The etiology of the colonic varix remains unclear at this time.

Treatment:
The patient did not receive any specific treatment during the hospitalization period.

Patient Instructions:
The patient was advised to follow the standard guidelines for maintaining good colon health and instructed to follow up with her primary care physician regarding any further symptoms or concerns.

Hospital Course:

Patient 5, a 57-year-old male with a history of hemophilia A and chronic hepatitis C, presented to clinic for routine follow-up appointments over the course of four years. He presented with symptoms of joint pain, recurrent and chronic hemarthrosis, and degenerative joint disease but had no indications of receiving hemophilia treatment during this time period.

Clinical Summary:

Based on the chart notes, Patient 5 is suspected to have moderate to severe hemophilia A as evidenced by his history of hemophilia and FVIII deficiency and presence of joint pain, recurrent and chronic hemarthrosis, and degenerative joint disease. However, given his chronic hepatitis C and lack of treatment over 4 years, it is unexpected for an individual with severe hemophilia.

Medical History:

Patient 5 has a history of chronic hepatitis C and hemophilia A. 

Discharge Instructions:

It is recommended that Patient 5 seek further treatment for his hemophilia A in order to prevent further joint damage and reduce the risk of hemarthrosis. He should also continue to receive ongoing care for his chronic hepatitis C. Follow-up appointments are recommended to monitor his symptoms and progress.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient presented with dysphagia and was diagnosed with a large hypoechoic tumor mass in the esophageal wall, possibly originating from either the submucosal or the muscular layer. Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) and enhanced computed tomography (CT) confirmed the tumor's 60mm length with its cranial edge identified at the level of the aortic arch, with characteristics suggestive of a benign esophageal schwannoma.

The patient underwent a combined endoscopic and thoracoscopic approach under general anesthesia. Endoscopic dissection was limited to about 30 mm of the tumor, following which the patient was placed in the prone position, and a left thoracoscopic access was achieved under 8 mmHg of artificial pneumothorax. The tumor was enucleated easily, and the mucosal layer was repaired.

The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and resumed an oral diet from postoperative day 7. The patient was discharged on postoperative day 9.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:

- Large benign esophageal schwannoma

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

- Follow-up with the primary care physician
- Avoid strenuous physical activity for a few weeks.
- Take pain medication as prescribed.
- Contact healthcare provider if symptoms worsen or return.

FOLLOW-UP CARE:

The patient is recommended to have follow-up care with their primary care physician.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Lobulated mass in 11–12 buccal region

Primary Clinical Impression: Pyogenic granuloma

Course of Treatment:
The patient presented with an asymptomatic lobulated mass in 11–12 buccal region that was bleeding upon pressure and compressible in nature. Simple excision was performed, and H and E staining revealed prominent endothelial proliferation and ulcerated epithelium with chronic inflammatory cells. The diagnosis was pyogenic granuloma, which is the most common of all reactive lesions and has a high female sex predilection. Chronic irritation precedes the inflammatory reaction and the increase in inflammatory cells in situ. In female patients, pyogenic granuloma formation is aided by female sex hormones and undergoes remission postpartum due to the increase in apoptotic factors such as tumor necrosis factor α.

Condition at Discharge: Stable

Follow-up Instructions: None

Discharge Medication: None

Follow-up Appointments: None

Discharge disposition: Discharged home

Attending Physician: [Redacted]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information: 
Name: [Redacted]
DOB: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Reason for Admission: 
The patient was admitted to the ED with acute onset of bilateral symmetrical numbness and tingling starting in the feet that ascended rapidly within few hours to the legs with associated motor weakness and inability to ambulate. 

Hospital Course: 
The patient was diagnosed with transverse myelitis based on MRI of the spine, which showed a lesion at the C7 level and high T2 intensity in the sacrum suggestive of inflammation. The patient was treated with steroids (methylprednisolone 1 g daily for 5 days followed by steroid taper over 2 weeks) and intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) (0.4 g/kg daily for 5 days). After five days, significant improvement was noted in the motor weakness and sensation of the bilateral lower limbs. The bladder function was eventually regained. 

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with transverse myelitis.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with steroids (methylprednisolone 1 g daily for 5 days followed by steroid taper over 2 weeks) and intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) (0.4 g/kg daily for 5 days).

Follow-up plan:
The patient was discharged to long-term rehabilitation. 

Final Diagnosis:
Transverse myelitis.

Summary:
A 17-year-old ambulating male with cerebral palsy presented to the ED with acute onset of bilateral symmetrical numbness and tingling. The patient was diagnosed with transverse myelitis based on MRI of the spine. The patient was treated with steroids and IVIG. After five days, significant improvement was noted in the motor weakness and sensation of the bilateral lower limbs. The bladder function was eventually regained. The patient was discharged to long-term rehabilitation.

Discharge Summary:

This discharge summary pertains to Antoine, a 13-year-old male who was brought to Ontario, Canada from the United States by his mother. Antoine made allegations of childhood abuse and severe physical discipline from his father, who was a joint legal guardian. He also identified as gay and feared a return to his father's home due to conservative religious beliefs that would not permit him to express his sexual identity.

Antoine was assessed by a Forensic Psychiatrist who reported he was a "mature minor," capable of understanding and appreciating the nature and consequences of his decisions, particularly those related to determining his country of residence. He also exhibited significant depressive symptoms that met criteria for Major Depressive Disorder.

An expert in Parental Alienation Syndrome (PAS) provided an opinion regarding Antoine's case. PAS is defined as a constellation of symptoms resulting from "brainwashing" by one parent resulting in the child's subsequent vilification of the target parent. The RSW concluded that Antoine's requests were not independent and should not be considered by the courts due to alleged "brainwashing" by his mother. The RSW offered a diagnosis of PAS in their assessment.

Ultimately, the court ruled that the child could pursue protections through local jurisdictional entities in the US and Antoine was returned to the custody of his father in the US.

This discharge summary serves as a brief overview and does not include any clinical information or details beyond what was explicitly mentioned in the case report.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Date]     
Discharge Date: [Date]

Patient Name: [Patient Name]  
Age: 55 years 
Sex: Female 

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with mild chest discomfort, which was determined to be related to a persistent B3 thymoma. The patient had undergone complete tumor resection with subsequent radiotherapy 12 years ago. However, the tumor recurred seven years ago with metastasis to both lungs, left subclavian node, and invasion of the pericardium and the mediastinum.
A debulking surgery was performed to remove as much of the tumor as possible, while avoiding injury to the right coronary artery. A drug eluting stent had previously been implanted in the RCA due to an incidental injury to the vessel during resection of the pericardial metastasis. There were no post-operative complications, and the patient recovered uneventfully. The patient was discharged with a recommendation for regular follow-up.

Diagnosis:
B3 Thymoma recurrence with mediastinal and pericardial invasion and metastasis to both lungs and left subclavian node. 

Follow-up: 
The patient is advised to attend regular follow-up appointments to monitor the disease progression and any further chest discomfort. 

Instructions:
1. Please avoid heavy lifting and strenuous physical activity for at least one month following discharge.
2. Perform activities of daily living (ADLs) as tolerated.
3. Please follow-up with your primary care physician or treating physician for required medications or changes in medications. 

Signed,
[Doctor's Name]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 9-year-old female, was admitted with asymptomatic lesions around the vulva and anus that had been present for 2 months. A physical examination revealed a firm, tender, 0.5 X 1.1 cm nodule on the left of the vulva and a pink 0.4 X 0.3 cm papule around the anus. An excisional biopsy was performed on both lesions, and histopathologic findings revealed a bulk of molluscum bodies surrounded by numerous keratinocytes. The diagnosis of molluscum contagiosum was confirmed by the histopathological and electron microscopy findings. There was no recurrence after a month of follow-up. Further assessment revealed no evidence of child abuse, and it was discovered that the patient often went swimming in a public pool.

Consultations:
Pathology: The pathology report indicated the presence of numerous molluscum bodies, which, combined with the other clinical evidence, led to the diagnosis of molluscum contagiosum.

Treatment and Follow-up:
The patient was treated and observed for 1 month without incident.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition without any further medical issues related to her molluscum contagiosum diagnosis. We have provided the patient's family with information on prevention and precautions to avoid further infections. The patient was advised to avoid public pools until the condition cleared up fully. There were no other issues that required continued medical attention.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 49-year-old Hispanic woman
Admission Date: March 2020
Discharge Date: Day 12

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Modena University Hospital's emergency room for symptoms including chest pain, cough, and fever. Upon admission, the patient was diagnosed with pneumonia and tested positive for SARS-CoV2. She was treated according to Regional Guidelines for COVID-19, with hydroxychloroquine, low-molecular-weight heparin, and antibiotic therapy. 

During the hospital stay, the patient developed symptoms of myocarditis, including chest pain, right bundle branch block, and moderate mitral insufficiency. Diagnostic imaging showed slight depression of the ejection fraction, increased myocardial T2 signal intensity, and pericardial effusion. 

Treatment was initiated with sotalol, acylsalicylic acid, and ramipril, which resulted in a reduction in symptoms and improvement of cardiac function. The patient was discharged on the 12th day of admission after improvement in symptoms and clearance of pericardial effusion. 

Follow-Up Instructions:
The patient should continue taking medications as prescribed and follow up with their primary care physician. The patient should maintain a healthy lifestyle and avoid strenuous activities for the next few weeks. The patient should monitor symptoms and seek medical attention if there is any recurrence or worsening of symptoms. 

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in a stable condition with improvement in symptoms and cardiac function.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [Date of admission]
Discharge Date: [Date of discharge]

Diagnosis: Ruptured aneurysm

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 49-year-old female, was admitted with a severe headache caused by a ruptured aneurysm. The patient had a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, smoking, and a stent for coronary artery stenosis. A saccular aneurysm on the left bifurcation of MCA was treated by stent-assisted coil embolization with Neuroform 3 stent. Immediate post-embolization angiography showed a nearly completely occluded aneurysm without any lesion around the stent. However, mild in-stent stenosis in the proximal portion of the stent was revealed on follow-up angiography 6 months later. Post-embolization 12-month angiography showed an occlusion of MCA from the portion of in-stent stenosis. She was unable to quit smoking at that time. Final angiography was performed at post-embolization 65 months, and angiographic findings were not changed. Fortunately, she had no symptoms associated with the obstruction of MCA. Her clinical course has been uneventful during the period of follow-up.

Treatment:
The patient received stent-assisted coil embolization with Neuroform 3 stent for saccular aneurysm on the left bifurcation of MCA.

Outcome:
The patient was discharged in good condition.

Follow-up:
The patient is to follow up with her primary care physician and neurologist as needed.

Instructions:
The patient is advised to quit smoking and to continue taking medications as prescribed by her healthcare provider.

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]
Hospital Admission Date: [Date]
Hospital Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission diagnosis: Acute periumbilical pain and hematochezia with hypovolemic shock.

Medical history: The patient previously underwent male to female gender reassignment surgery 18 months earlier with occasional symptoms of recurrent abdominal pain.

Diagnostic test results: Abdominal X-ray showed dilated small bowel without free air and, during ultrasound-guided paracentesis, unclotted blood was found in the abdominal cavity, which led to the diagnosis of hemoperitoneum.

Treatment: An emergency laparotomy was performed, during which 100-cm hemorrhagic necrosis of a segment of jejunum was discovered due to post-surgical fibrous adhesions. The necrotic small bowel was removed. Microscopic examination showed transmural vascular congestion and hemorrhagic necrosis in the sections of the small bowel, with normal lumen of mesenteric arteries. After the operation, the patient remained well and did not experience any complications.

Follow-up care: Follow-up appointments were scheduled with the appropriate medical professionals to ensure overall health and well-being.

Discharge instructions: The patient was discharged in good condition with instructions to continue follow-up appointments.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Length of Stay: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to our emergency room complaining of an enlargement of the left breast accompanied by pain. A breast ultrasound was conducted, followed by an MRI, which showed a well-circumscribed mass consistent with a PT. The patient then underwent a wide local excision of the lesion. A histopathological examination confirmed the presence of PT, with mild hypercellularity and myxoid changes accounting for ≥50% of the tumor volume. There were no complications during the hospitalization, and the patient was discharged after resolution of the symptoms.

Medical Diagnosis:
Pleomorphic Adenoma of the Breast (PT)

Treatment:
The patient underwent a wide local excision of the lesion to treat PT.

Follow-up:
The patient has been followed up for five years by annual breast ultrasounds, during which no reoccurrences were reported, with no appreciable difference was observed between the symmetry during development.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in a stable condition with resolution of the symptoms.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 17-year-old female, was admitted due to a history of intense headache, two episodes of vomiting, and sudden loss of consciousness. On examination, the patient was unconscious with sluggishly reacting pupils. The computed tomography (CT) of the brain revealed gross hydrocephalus with an ill-defined cystic lesion in the dilated third ventricle. The patient was diagnosed with intra-ventricular neurocysticercosis (IVNCC) and underwent emergency endoscopic surgery. The endoscopic third ventriculostomy (ETV) was performed to prevent delayed hydrocephalus. Postoperative recovery was good, and there were no added postoperative deficits.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
The patient was diagnosed with IVNCC confirmed by histopathological examination. Albendazole was prescribed for one week, and she continued on antiepileptic medication for six months. There was no evidence of hydrocephalus in the six-month follow-up CT scan. At two years follow-up, the patient is doing well.

Summary:
A 17-year-old female was admitted due to intense headache, vomiting, and sudden loss of consciousness. The patient was diagnosed with IVNCC, and an emergency endoscopic surgery was performed to remove a solitary cyst and prevent delayed hydrocephalus. The patient recovered well postoperatively and was treated with albendazole and antiepileptic medication. There was no evidence of hydrocephalus in a six-month follow-up CT scan, and the patient is doing well at a two-year follow-up.

Hospital Course:

The patient was a 27-year-old pregnant woman who presented with recurrent panic attacks and other anxiety symptoms. On evaluation, it was revealed that she was a known case of panic disorder, and getting medication for the same. She continued the treatment for 1½ year and then stopped the medication with the advice of the therapist. After that, she started having anxiety about the health of the baby and the outcome of the pregnancy.

Physical Exam:

On clinical examination and blood investigations, including thyroid profile, ultrasound, electrocardiogram, and vitals, including blood pressure, were within the normal limit.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient was assessed on generalized anxiety disorder-7 (GAD-7) and scored a moderate to a high level of anxiety. Pharmacological and non-pharmacological therapy were offered and explained the pros and cons of the drugs. The patient and family member opted for biofeedback therapy and breathing exercise. Biofeedback therapy sessions were started with regular monitoring of the severity of symptoms on GAD-7 and clinically. Initially, 2–3 sessions/week, 30–45 min, were given for 3 weeks, which led to 60%–70% improvement. Gradually, frequency of session reduced to 1/week and had complete improvement in 2 months. After that, she would visit 1–2 times/month and delivered a normal baby at full term by normal vaginal delivery without any adverse consequences.

Disposition and Condition at Discharge:

The patient was discharged in stable condition with complete resolution of her anxiety symptoms through biofeedback therapy and breathing exercise.

HOSPITAL COURSE:

This 44-year-old Japanese woman was admitted for simultaneous resection of an atypical thymic carcinoid and a cardiac myxoma via a midline sternotomy. The patient had a history of hypertension and uterine myoma, for which she was taking angiotensin II receptor blocker and calcium channel blocker. During a regular health check-up, an abnormality in the left mediastinum was discovered through chest roentgenography. A CT scan of the chest revealed a 100 × 90 mm mass in the anterior mediastinum, with no surrounding organ invasion, and a 30 × 30 mm mass in the left atrium. Transthoracic echocardiography showed a movable mass attached to the mitral valve that prolapsed into the left ventricle. The patient was diagnosed with an atypical thymic carcinoid through CT-guided needle biopsy. The patient underwent successful resection of both tumors without any complications. The patient recovered well and was followed up with regular physical examinations, chest roentgenography, echocardiography, and CT scans every 6 months. No recurrence was seen as of the 45-month follow-up.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:

1. Atypical thymic carcinoid
2. Cardiac myxoma

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

The patient was discharged in a stable condition. She was advised to continue taking her current medications as prescribed by her primary care physician. She was instructed to follow up with her primary care physician and continue regular check-ups to monitor for any recurrence or complications. She was advised to report any symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, or palpitations immediately.

FOLLOW-UP PLAN:

The patient will continue to be followed up with regular physical examinations, chest roentgenography, echocardiography, and CT scans every 6 months to monitor for any recurrence or complications.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 79-year-old Japanese woman with a weight of 72 kg

Admission: The patient was admitted to the hospital with elevated creatinine levels, proteinuria, and microscopic hematuria.

Hospitalization: The patient was diagnosed with pauci-immune necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis and was initially considered to have hydralazine-induced myeloperoxidase-antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody-associated vasculitis. The serum creatinine level decreased gradually after discontinuation of hydralazine. However, the patient experienced a relapse of the condition 16 months later, which was treated with prednisone. The patient achieved remission after five months of treatment.

Investigations: The patient's serum samples were obtained at different stages to assess the involvement of neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs). The NET degradation activity was entirely low in all serum samples compared to the healthy control. The NET induction activity of IgG isolated from the serum samples was high in the initial serum samples and decreased with treatment. The results of immunofluorescent tests were consistent with the ELISA titers of myeloperoxidase-antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies.

Follow-Up: The patient has remained in remission after successful treatment. Further follow-up is recommended to monitor the patient's condition.

Discharge Diagnosis: Pauci-immune necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis, initial hydralazine-induced myeloperoxidase-antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody-associated vasculitis and subsequent relapse.

Discharge Medications: None.

Discharge Plan: The patient is advised to continue with follow-up appointments to monitor her condition. Lifestyle modifications, including a healthy diet and exercise, should be adopted. Additional treatment options, if necessary, will be discussed with the patient during follow-up appointments.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 57-year-old woman with a history of cervix carcinoma and pulmonary tuberculosis, was diagnosed with stage III B lambda light chain MM in January 2003. She initially presented with acute renal failure. Upon diagnosis, laboratory tests showed low kidney function, as well as high levels of proteinuria and glomerular filtration rate (GFR). MRI revealed osteolytic lesions. It was determined that the patient had MM.

Treatment:
The patient underwent chemotherapy with Vincristine, Adriamycin, and Dexamethasone (VAD) and achieved near-complete remission. Following this treatment, the patient underwent an autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (autoHSCT) in June 2003 and was found to have complete remission. In September 2005, the patient presented with elevated levels of BJP, and second-line chemotherapy with Thalidomide and Dexamethasone was started, reducing BJP levels and leading to the patient's neuropathy recovery. Thalidomide was discontinued following a period to prevent neuropathy symptoms from affecting the patient.

Outcome:
The patient underwent increasing renal function recovery following the autoHSCT procedure. Over time, kidney function improved to the point of discontinuing dialysis treatment in July 2007. As of July 2008, the patient remains off dialysis treatment, with continued kidney function improvement.

Summary:
A 57-year-old woman diagnosed with MM received chemotherapy and an autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Following the second chemotherapy treatment with Thalidomide, the patient complained of neuropathy, leading to discontinuing the medication. The patient recovered from the MM diagnosis following an extended period of recovery. In July 2007, the patient was able to discontinue dialysis treatment and remains off treatment with continued kidney function improvement.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 44-year-old male with end-stage renal disease caused by diabetes mellitus and hypertension.

Hospital Course: The patient underwent a kidney transplant from the same donor as Case 4. However, due to delayed graft function, he required hemodialysis and was treated with tigecycline and ceftazidime-avibactam for prevention and treatment of carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae (CRKP). The patient developed allograft hydronephrosis and underwent percutaneous transplanting renal puncture and fistula drainage, which resulted in CRKP growth in the urine drainage. The patient developed fever with an increase in bacteriuria and leukocytosis, and bleeding was found coincidentally at the puncture and drainage area. An emergency exploratory operation revealed the rupture of the anastomotic stoma of the transplanted renal artery and the external iliac artery, which necessitated graft nephrectomy combined with debridement. After eight weeks of tigecycline and ceftazidime-avibactam treatment, the infection was cured without evidence of CRKP.

Hospital Course Summary:
- Transplant from same donor as Case 4
- Delayed graft function required hemodialysis
- Treated with tigecycline and ceftazidime-avibactam for prevention and treatment of CRKP
- Developed allograft hydronephrosis and underwent percutaneous transplanting renal puncture and fistula drainage
- CRKP growth in urine drainage
- Developed fever with an increase in bacteriuria and leukocytosis
- Bleeding found at puncture and drainage area
- Emergency exploratory operation revealed rupture of anastomotic stoma of transplanted renal artery and external iliac artery, necessitating graft nephrectomy combined with debridement
- Eight weeks of tigecycline and ceftazidime-avibactam treatment cured infection without evidence of CRKP.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not Provided
Age: 71
Sex: Female

Admission Date: Not Provided
Discharge Date: Not Provided
Length of Stay: 9 days

Reason for Admission: Shortness of breath, nonproductive cough, and fatigue

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to progressive dyspnea on exertion, minimally productive cough, significant fatigue, and nonbloody diarrhea. She was febrile and had a low oxygen saturation rate. Computed tomography of the chest revealed bilateral peribronchovascular ground-glass opacities. The patient was placed on supplemental oxygen and underwent repeat SARS-CoV-2 NP PCR tests which were negative. Flow cytometry of peripheral blood demonstrated no circulating B-cells, and an immunoglobulin panel demonstrated low levels of IgM, IgG, and IgA consistent with a history of receiving rituximab. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) was positive for SARS-CoV-2 PCR. The patient was treated and slowly weaned off supplemental oxygen. She was discharged from the hospital after 9 days.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was diagnosed with shortness of breath, nonproductive cough, and fatigue. She was admitted to the hospital and tested positive for SARS-CoV-2. CT scans of the chest revealed bilateral peribronchovascular ground-glass opacities. The patient received supplemental oxygen. She had low levels of IgM, IgG, and IgA consistent with a history of receiving rituximab. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) was positive for SARS-CoV-2 PCR. After being treated and weaned off supplemental oxygen, the patient was discharged after 9 days.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: Unavailable
Sex: Male
Age: 84
Admission date: mid-May 2017
Discharge date: Unavailable
Admitting Diagnosis: Worsening shortness of breath, orthopnea, and inability to move around.
Discharge Diagnosis: Unavailable

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for shortness of breath at our hospital. He had a history of severe oxygen-dependent COPD, chronic diastolic heart failure, obstructive sleep apnea, type II diabetes mellitus, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, tricuspid regurgitation, cor pulmonale, previous coronary artery bypass and chronic kidney disease stage IIIB. During admission, his oxygen saturation was improved by high flow oxygen. Jugular venous distension was present, and he had bilateral pitting pretibial edema. A grossly elevated level of Pro B Naturetic Peptide was found. His creatinine levels were also elevated. The lungs revealed bilateral basal inspiratory crepitations. Cardiomegaly, hypoventilation, bibasilar atelectasis, and pulmonary vascular congestion were identified through chest radiography. Echocardiogram revealed severe right atrial enlargement.

Treatment:
The patient was put on continuous infusion Furosemide at 20 mg/h, together with concurrent intravenous Chlorothiazide 500 mg every 8 h. Diuresis was successful in just over 12 h, and over the next two days, he had increased urine output and decreasing weight. He was switched to oral Torsemide, 20 mg twice daily, together with oral Metolazone, 2.5 mg Every other day as adjunct diuretic agent.

Discharge Plan:
The patient was discharged to the Nursing Home, where he became weak and opted for hospice care shortly after discharge. He peacefully passed away about a week later.

Follow-up:
N/A

Impressions and Recommendations:
N/A

Hospital course:
The patient presented with severe blunt head trauma. Physical exam revealed trauma to the left temporal area with a large hematoma and bloody discharge from the left ear. FAST was negative for intraperitoneal and pericardial fluid, and plain films of the chest and pelvis were negative for acute injuries. While being prepared for transport for CT, the patient experienced an increase in intracranial pressure and went into cardiac arrest. CPR was performed and ultimately, the patient had a subdural hematoma and concomitant subarachnoid hemorrhage leading to tonsillar herniation. Despite efforts to manage the situation, the patient passed away. 

Summary:
A 65-year-old man with no known past medical history presented with severe blunt head trauma and was found to have a large hematoma with bloody discharge. Despite attempts to treat an increase in intracranial pressure and cardiac arrest, the patient ultimately passed away due to subdural hematoma and concomitant subarachnoid hemorrhage leading to tonsillar herniation.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 45-year-old female who presented with posterior neck pain, numbness, and transient weakness on both arms that had persisted for six months. The pain and weakness had worsened after a recent light traffic accident. The patient has no prior medical or surgical history, but had suffered a bicycle traffic accident five years ago. On physical examination, weakness (grade IV) for her both grasping and radiculopathy through both the sixth vertebrae (C6) and the seventh vertebrae (C7) dermatome was noted. Radiographic examination of the patient's cervical spine revealed a bilateral spondylolysis on C6 and spondylolisthesis at C6 on C7. Additionally, flexion and extension lateral views showed instability between C6 and C7. On CT scan, a bilateral defect between the pedicle and the lamina was revealed, and spina bifida occulta was noted at the C6 level. On MRI, cord compression was not definitive, but the bilateral neural foramen was compressed. The neurologic symptoms warranted a surgical intervention, and an anterior cervical discectomy and fusion on C6 and C7 with posterior decompression and fusion using C5 lateral mass–C7 pedicle screw fixation were performed. Postoperatively, the patient's symptoms improved significantly.

Hospital Course: 

The patient, a 9-month-old baby girl from Cameroon, was admitted to our hospital with a snake-like rash on her abdomen. She had no fever, cough, or other systemic symptoms. On physical examination, multiple erythematous, raised, and thin serpiginous lesions of varying lengths were found over her trunk and arms.

Diagnosis: 

The patient was diagnosed with cutaneous larva migrans (CLM).

Treatment: 

The patient was treated with albendazole syrup for 3 consecutive days and chlorpheniramine syrup for 3 days. Topical ivermectin cream was prescribed and the patient experienced complete resolution of the lesions at follow-up, 1 week later.

Follow-Up: 

At the follow-up visit 3 days after treatment initiation, the patient's irritability had resolved, although a few serpiginous lesions persisted.

Instructions: 

No further instructions were provided.

Summary: 

A 9-month-old baby girl from Cameroon was diagnosed with cutaneous larva migrans (CLM) after presenting with a reddish, snake-like rash on her abdomen. She was treated with albendazole syrup, chlorpheniramine syrup, and topical ivermectin cream, resulting in complete resolution of the lesions. At the follow-up visit 3 days after treatment initiation, the patient exhibited no further irritability, although a few serpiginous lesions still persisted. No further instructions were provided.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 88-year-old female

Admission: Coronary Care Unit

Diagnosis: Atrioventricular Block, Third Degree

History: Admission was two weeks after the patient experienced dizziness and shortness of breath. The extended history revealed she had three episodes of falling and syncope in the months prior to admission, but the cause of these episodes had not yet been investigated. Electrocardiography (ECG) at admission revealed third-degree atrioventricular block with an abnormally low heart rate.

Treatment: The patient was diagnosed with Alzheimer's Disease with paranoid symptoms 24 months prior to admission and started medication for it. She was also being treated for hypertension with medications. It was concluded that the atrioventricular block was caused by her medication for Alzheimer's Disease and this was discontinued. She was then given temporary pacemaker treatment, followed by a permanent pacemaker.

Observations: The patient had no history of ischemic heart disease and no chest pain. The physical examination at admission and discharge revealed no positive neurological deficits other than her known cognitive dysfunction. The patient experienced slightly elevated cardiac biomarkers but echocardiography was found to be normal. The patient had slight electrolyte imbalances in sodium and calcium levels but normal red and white blood counts.

Discharge Plan: The patient was discharged to her own home with a permanent pacemaker. After being discharged, the patient decided not to reinitiate the medication for Alzheimer's Disease.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 49-year-old female

Medical History: N/A

Admission Date: N/A

Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course: The patient presented with hair loss and pruritus lasting for one year, which had not improved with minoxidil therapy. Examination revealed scarring alopecia with follicular papules and mild scaling over the vertex. She also had recession of frontotemporal hairline with bilaterally symmetrical band-like scarring alopecia of the same region, along with numerous violaceous follicular spinous papules distributed over the abdomen, back, arms, and legs. A diagnosis of GLPS with FFA was made based on the patient's findings.

Treatment: The patient was treated with oral prednisolone (1 mg/kg/day) and oral retinoid (0.5 mg/kg/day) for the initial two weeks, followed by the dose of steroid being tapered to 20 mg/day and continued along with the same dose of oral isotretinoin (20 mg) for another two weeks, with strict monitoring of blood parameters without any alteration. At the end of one month, the patient had significant improvement of pruritus and hair loss with flattening of the follicular papules. Doses of steroid and isotretinoin were further reduced to 10 mg/day and 15 mg/day, respectively, for another one month, with further flattening of follicular papules and improvement of FFA patch. The patient is now on only 15 mg oral retinoid every alternate day and with regular follow-up on a monthly basis. Follicular papules almost resolved with residual postinflammatory hyperpigmentation.

Outcome: The patient showed significant improvement following the treatment and is due for a follow-up visit.

Hospital Course:
The 51-year-old male patient presented to the department of oral medicine and radiology with a complaint of pain and swelling on the left side of the floor of the mouth. On clinical examination, a hard mass was palpable on the floor of the mouth on the left side with a small ulceration towards the midline. The patient was diagnosed with a salivary gland stone and was planned for surgery under local anesthesia.

Discharge Summary:
The patient underwent surgical removal of a salivary gland stone located on the floor of the mouth. The stone was approximately 15mm in size and was fragmented during surgical removal. The half fragment exfoliated itself the night before surgery, and the other half of the fragment was removed by surgery. Patency of the duct was maintained by inserting a drain, and the area was sutured. Postoperative analgesic and antiseptic mouthwash were prescribed. The patient was followed-up two weeks post-operatively, and the left submandibular gland was palpable, but clear saliva could be expressed from the duct. The patient had an unremarkable postoperative course and was dismissed from care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
• Name:  <Patient's Name>
• Age:  67-year-old
• Gender: Male

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with a history of dyspnea and right calf swelling. Computed tomography angiography (CTA) of the chest showed massive filling defects in the right and left pulmonary arteries. Duplex ultrasound confirmed right femoral deep venous thrombosis (DVT), hence the patient was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

Medical History:
The patient had been diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) for nine years and had undergone an ankle surgery nine months ago. He was treated with multiple combinations of disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) and corticosteroids. About three years ago, he started taking etanercept (25 mg twice weekly).

Laboratory Results:
The patient had an elevated activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) of 48 seconds prior to initiating anticoagulation therapy. He tested positive for LAC (Lupus anticoagulant) and ANA (Antinuclear antibodies), with a speckled pattern at titer of 1:1280. ACL IgG and IgM were within normal range. Further thrombophilia workup was negative.

Treatment:
The patient was started on anticoagulation therapy to treat the DVT and pulmonary embolism.

Follow-up:
The patient has been advised to follow up after being discharged to monitor his condition and ensure proper medication management.

Summary:
A 67-year-old Hispanic male with a history of rheumatoid arthritis, who had been treated with multiple drugs, presented with dyspnea, right calf swelling, and was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. The patient showed elevated aPTT levels, tested positive for LAC and ANA with a speckled pattern, and was started on anticoagulation therapy to treat his condition. Follow-up is advised to ensure proper medication management.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 52-year-old male internist with a positive SARS-CoV-2 diagnosis.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted on August 24, 2020, with myalgias, arthralgias, general condition attack, dry cough, dyspnea, odynophagia, and dyspnea of moderate efforts. He had a positive RT-PCR for SARS-CoV-2 of nasopharyngeal exudate on August 27, 2020. The patient required hospitalization due to oxygen saturation dropping to 77% despite supplemental oxygen intake. Advanced airway management was initiated for 11 days, and he was admitted to the intensive care unit. A simple chest CT scan performed on August 31 showed distribution of bilateral multilobar ground glass opacity, with areas of consolidation in the posterior segments of the upper and lower lobes, interlobular septal thickening associated with ground glass mainly in the upper lobes of the right lung, atelectasis in the lower lobes, lingula, and middle lobe. The patient responded to treatment and was discharged on November 17, 2020.

Recommendations:
The patient is advised to continue medical treatment and to follow up with their internist regularly. He is also encouraged to engage in self-care measures such as hand hygiene, social distancing, and wearing a mask in public, to reduce the risk of contracting and spreading infection.

Follow-up:
The patient is scheduled to return for follow-up visits with his internist to monitor his overall health and progress. He is advised to seek immediate medical attention if symptoms of recurrence or new symptoms develop.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: (Patient's name)

Date of Admission: (Date of admission)

Date of Discharge: (Date of discharge)

Discharge Diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma of sigmoid colon

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for further examination after being diagnosed with a sigmoid colon lesion. A colonoscopy revealed a 12 mm type 0-Is lesion in the sigmoid colon, which was diagnosed as an adenoma or intramucosal cancer. The lesion was removed by piecemeal resection, and the post-resection defect was closed with metallic endoclips. Histopathological examination confirmed a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma with low grade atypia, and the treatment was considered a curative resection.

Follow up colonoscopies were performed 1 and 3 years after endoscopic resection, and no residual or recurrent lesion was detected. A follow-up colonoscopy was scheduled at 5 years after treatment, but it was cancelled for personal reasons.

In 2007, the patient's third follow-up colonoscopy revealed a protruding submucosal tumor (SMT), 20 mm in size at the site of the previous endoscopic resection. Histopathological diagnosis confirmed an adenocarcinoma, and a laparoscopic-assisted sigmoidectomy with D3 lymph node resection was performed. Histopathological analysis of the resected lesion revealed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with lymph node metastasis, lymphovascular invasion, venous invasion, and perineural invasion.

The patient recovered well after surgery and was discharged with appropriate follow-up instructions. The patient was advised to continue follow-up care with their primary care provider and to undergo frequent colonoscopies to monitor for any future recurrence or new lesions.

Discharge Medications:

None

Follow-Up Instructions:

The patient was advised to continue follow-up care with their primary care provider and to undergo frequent colonoscopies to monitor for any future recurrence or new lesions.

Hospital Course: Patient presented to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident with loss of consciousness and persistent bradycardia. He had facial abrasions and epistaxis, but no evidence of cerebrospinal fluid otorrhea or rhinorrhea, or extremity deformity. He was found to have bradycardia and pulseless electrical activity followed by timely resuscitation. Glasgow Coma Scale score was E1VTM1 and bilateral pupil size was 3.5 mm without light reflex. ECG findings revealed ST-segment elevation in leads II and V3-6, suspected acute myocardial infarction, and subsequent atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response and ST-segment depression. Bedside cardiac ultrasound showed grossly normal wall motion of the left ventricle while diagnostic coronary angiography revealed coronary artery spasm and a myocardial bridge of the left anterior descending artery, with no occluded segments or flow-limiting lesions.
 
Management and Treatment: Patient was placed on extracorporeal membrane oxygenation due to poor response to inotropic agents and suspected liver laceration with hemoperitoneum. The administration of an intracoronary nitroglycerin injection led to significant increase in the native left coronary artery and right coronary artery diameters. Left ventriculogram showed mild mitral valve regurgitation and mild hypokinesia of the inferior wall. Left ventricular ejection fraction was 60% under ECMO and inotropic agents; however, patient remained with a low cardiac output and eventually progressed into shock and died.

Patient Condition and Prognosis: Despite adequate resuscitation, the patient's condition continued to progressively deteriorate, leading to his eventual death.

Hospital Course:

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: N/A
DOB: 1951
Gender: Male

Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A
Length of Stay: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 64-year-old male former smoker with IPF who presented to our hospital after developing dyspnea 65 days after initiating the treatment dose of nintedanib. Chest CT revealed newly developed diffuse ground glass opacities, and laboratory investigation revealed high serum levels of Krebs von den Lungen-6, surfactant protein D, and lactate dehydrogenase. The possibility of infection, left-sided heart failure, and pulmonary embolism was ruled out, and an acute exacerbation of IPF was diagnosed.

In accordance with the study protocol, nintedanib was discontinued and intensive treatment was initiated comprising methyl prednisolone pulse therapy, direct hemoperfusion using a polymyxin B immobilized fiber column, intravenous cyclophosphamide, and cyclosporine. Subsequently, the patient's clinical symptoms, PaO2/FiO2 ratio, and imaging findings gradually improved.

After careful observation, nintedanib was readministered 30 days after it had been stopped. Although his FVC temporarily decreased after the acute exacerbation, it remained stable from May 2012 to January 2013. Nintedanib was safely continued without the recurrence of acute exacerbations until the patient died of a bacterial infection in February 2014.

Hospital Discharge:
The patient remained in our care until his passing in February 2014.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Admission Date: April 2007
Discharge Date:

Patient Name: [Patient Name]
Age: 58
Gender: Male

Admitting Diagnosis:
Suspected metastasis of sigmoid cancer in Couinaud segment 7

History:
The patient underwent resection of colon sigmoideum due to carcinoma in 2003. Additionally, he suffered from mild hypertension and non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with a suspected metastasis of sigmoid cancer in Couinaud segment 7. An abdominal ultrasound was performed, and a CT scan was ordered. The CT scan showed a liver metastasis in Couinaud segment 7 with a size of 2.2 × 2.4 cm that was closely attached to the right hepatic vein. Analysis of the CT scan revealed that the proximal part of the middle hepatic vein was completely missing, whereas its distal branches seemed to be open. An additional 3D imaging of the case was done to get more detailed information about the anatomical situation. As the non-existence of a middle hepatic vein may have led to insufficient drainage of remnant hepatic parenchyma following a bisegmental resection of CS 6 and 7, a right-sided hemihepatectomy was performed. The pathologic examination confirmed the diagnosis of colorectal liver metastasis. The patient's intra- and postoperative courses were uneventful. He was discharged on the eighth postoperative day.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient is advised to complete his follow-up visits as recommended by his physician.

Discharge Condition:
Stable

Discharge Medications:
None

Follow-up Appointments:
Recommended by his physician.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to continue taking his medications as prescribed, maintain a healthy lifestyle, and follow up with his physician as recommended. He was also encouraged to contact his physician immediately if he experiences any new symptoms or if his condition worsens.
