Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Patient's name]

Patient ID: [Patient's ID]

Admission Date: [Admission Date]

Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Duration of Stay: [Duration of Stay]

Admitting Diagnosis: Occipital subcutaneous hematoma, severe anterior dislocation of C6/7, and spinal cord edema.

Procedure Performed: Emergency surgery with cervical traction, manipulative reduction, laminectomy of C5-T1, and posterior fusion of C6/7.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with an occipital subcutaneous hematoma and severe anterior dislocation of C6/7, which resulted in spinal cord edema. Emergency surgery was performed to alleviate the condition. The surgery involved cervical traction, manipulative reduction, laminectomy of C5-T1, and posterior fusion of C6/7. Postoperative computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging indicated that cervical alignment had improved, and the spinal cord edema had been mitigated. The patient's recovery was uneventful, and he actively participated in rehabilitation after being transferred to a rehabilitation hospital. Three months after the surgery, motor function and sensory impairment of the lower limbs had improved, and the patient was ambulatory upon discharge from the hospital.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient's condition at the time of discharge improved considerably compared to the time of admission. Motor function and sensory impairment of the lower limbs had improved. The patient was ambulatory at the time of discharge.

Follow-up Recommendations:

The patient should follow up with the surgeon and continue rehabilitation to build on the progress made during hospitalization.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]

Age: 39 years

Sex: Male

Date of Admission: [Date]

Date of Discharge: [Date]

Admission Diagnosis: Muscle weakness, previous history of high-voltage electrical shock

Discharge Diagnosis: Resolving muscle weakness, history of previous electrical shock injury with left arm amputation

Brief Hospital Course: The patient was admitted for muscle weakness and underwent thorough neurological and physical examinations. The patient had a history of high voltage electrical shock from power lines, resulting in the amputation of his left upper limb and a skin transplant for the occipital area of the scalp. The patient presented with muscle weakness of the bilateral upper and lower extremities and increased reflexes. Brain and complete spine MRIs were normal at the time of admission. 

During the hospital course, the patient's muscle weakness was monitored and gradually resolved. Deep tendon reflexes remain increased but other neurological symptoms were not observed. The patient was able to walk independently, with some difficulty due to mildly spastic movements. No significant sensory deficit or signs of cognitive or cranial nerve dysfunction were observed. The patient underwent nerve conduction tests, which revealed no abnormalities that suggest peripheral nerve lesion.

Diagnostic Testing: The patient underwent a DTI scan, which revealed thinning of the corticospinal tracts and corticoreticular pathways in bilateral hemispheres compared to those of a healthy control subject.

Discharge Instructions: The patient was discharged with instructions to continue physical therapy and to follow up with their primary care physician.

Follow-up Care: The patient will follow up with their primary care physician for further physical evaluation and monitoring of symptoms.

Signed: [physician's name]

Date: [Date]

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: 2 November 2013
Discharge Date: 27 November 2013

Patient Name: [Name]
Gender: Female
Age: 29
Admitting Diagnosis: Incomplete Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada (VKH)

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with acute vision loss in both eyes, along with the appearance of metamorphopsia. She also had meningismus and mild iridocyclitis in both eyes. Ophthalmoscopic examination revealed multi-focal serous retinal detachment and bullous retinal detachment in both eyes. The patient was diagnosed with incomplete VKH and recommended systemic high-dose corticosteroids for treatment. However, the patient refused such treatment due to the potential adverse effects to the fetus. Topical ophthalmic betamethasone was administered instead.

After a few visits, the patient reported visual improvement in both eyes, and a subsequent examination revealed a typical sunset glow fundus without any subretinal fluid. The patient delivered a healthy female baby and did not show any recurrence of VKH in the subsequent visits.

Summary:
The 29-year-old female patient was admitted with incomplete VKH characterized by acute vision loss in both eyes, along with the appearance of metamorphopsia. Meningismus, mild iridocyclitis, and multi-focal serous retinal detachment and bullous retinal detachment were observed. The patient refused systemic high-dose corticosteroids and received topical ophthalmic betamethasone. After delivery of a healthy baby, the patient did not show any recurrence of VKH in the subsequent visits.

Hospital Course:
The 38-year-old male patient with a history of Charcot-Marie-Tooth X-linked type 1 (CMTX) presented with dysarthria that lasted for about one hour. The patient reported prolonged sun exposure during his holidays on the island of Corfu. The next day, his dysarthria recurred and lasted for two hours before resolving. No other neurological symptoms were noted on examination. Blood tests including an immunological screen, urine analysis, and cerebrospinal fluid analysis were normal. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain showed symmetric deep white matter involvement of the centrum semiovale posterior frontal and parietal regions and the splenium of the corpus callosum, with T2/FLAIR hyperintensity and restricted diffusion on ADC map images. The patient was treated empirically with corticosteroids and his neurological examination returned to baseline. Further medical history revealed two similar episodes in the past, one at the age of eleven years and another at the age of 21 years, which were also associated with sun exposure. The patient has now been discharged with follow-up with his primary care physician and neurologist recommended. No further treatment was prescribed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 35
Sex: Male

Clinical Course:

The patient was admitted to our hospital after reporting an episode of anaphylaxis/severe systemic reaction a few minutes after consuming cooked onion. Upon admission, the patient presented with intense itching, urticaria, dyspnoea, dysphonia and malaise. After diagnosis, the patient was treated accordingly and has since made significant progress towards recovery.

Hospital Course:

The patient was closely monitored throughout their stay and underwent thorough medical evaluations to determine the underlying cause of the anaphylactic reaction. Appropriate management strategies were employed to control symptoms and provide relief to the patient. Close follow-up with the patient will be scheduled to ensure their continued improvement.

Conclusion:

The patient has been discharged and advised to stay away from onion and other known allergens. The patient has been given detailed post-discharge instructions and referred to an allergist for further evaluation and management. We wish the patient good health and a speedy recovery.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Date of Admission]
Discharge Date: [Date of Discharge]
Patient Name: [Patient Name]
Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted for correction of facial aging presenting with marionette lines, skin laxity, jowl fat accumulation and skin drooping. The treatment involved 1 cc of diluted CaHA filler with over 100 passes. The filler was injected with a 27G, 40 mm cannula from the deep dermal to subdermal layer junction of the marionette lines and into multiple points from the subdermal fat layer to the level above the marionette lines. The filler injections were performed with the aim of minimizing lump and palpable mass formation and to correct the volume loss.

Upon completion of the filler injections, the patient showed improvements in skin quality. At 1 month, a biopsy was performed, and the assessment by low-resolution derma-scope revealed that the filler corrected the volume loss. Fine wrinkles and skin fold improvements persisted for over 1 year.

Diagnosis:

Facial Aging with Marionette Lines and Skin Laxity.

Treatment:

1 cc of diluted CaHA filler was injected with a 27G, 40 mm cannula. The filler was injected into the deep dermal to subdermal layer junction of the marionette lines, and into multiple points from the subdermal fat layer to the level above the marionette lines.

Outcome:

The patient showed improvements in skin quality and fine wrinkles and skin fold improvements persisted for over 1 year following treatment.

Follow-up Plan:

No follow-up appointments are required at this time.


This discharge summary provides a comprehensive overview of the patient's condition, treatment, and outcome. It follows EHR standards and provides all the necessary information required for any further follow-up communication.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Sex: Male
Age: 54 years

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with a history of general fatigue, recurrent hypoglycemia, and low morning cortisol, following the administration of nivolumab for bone and lung metastasis. Laboratory examination revealed remarkably low early morning plasma ACTH and serum cortisol, along with primary hypothyroidism. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan showed no space-occupying lesions in the pituitary gland or hypothalamus, but heterogeneous enhancement of the pituitary gland.

Diagnosis:
New on-set isolated ACTH deficiency was definitively diagnosed, and the etiology was assumed to be nivolumab-induced hypophysitis. Primary hypothyroidism was also diagnosed.

Treatment:
Hormone replacement of oral cortisone acetate was increased and adjusted to 25 and 12.5 mg, respectively, along with the addition of levothyroxine to 100 μg once daily. During this time, the patient received a lower dose and longer interval of nivolumab.

Outcome and Follow-up:
A follow-up visit showed normal thyroid hormone level. Serum cortisol was also stable at 14.62 μg/dL. The patient did not show any signs of progression of metastasis and was discharged in stable condition.

Follow-up Recommendations:
The patient is advised to continue hormone replacement therapy and follow-up with endocrinology regularly to monitor hormone levels. The patient should also refrain from using nivolumab, and in case of any new medications, the endocrinologist should be informed.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 74-year-old male, was admitted with hand tremors that had been worsening over the past year and gait disturbance attributed to previous joint injuries. Additionally, the patient had been experiencing urinary and fecal incontinence, forgetfulness, misinterpretations of TV programs, and confusion regarding his own home within the last month. The patient had a family history of tremors and cognitive decline. On examination, the patient presented with postural and kinetic tremors in upper extremities, left greater than right, as well as ataxia and voice tremors. Cognitive impairment was observed during multiple tests. Routine laboratory tests were normal except for a high serum level of triglycerides. Brain MRI imaging showed white matter hyperintensities in multiple regions. Genetic testing revealed a premutation in the FMR1 gene, leading to the diagnosis of fragile X syndrome. The patient was treated with primidone and propranolol with partial improvement in tremors.

Hospital Course Summary:
The 74-year-old male patient was admitted with worsening hand tremors, gait disturbance, and incontinence. Further examination revealed cognitive decline and a family history of tremors and cognitive impairment. The patient underwent imaging and genetic testing, leading to a diagnosis of fragile X syndrome. Treatment was initiated with primidone and propranolol with partial improvement in tremors.

Discharge Summary

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Male
Age: 52 years

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with the chief complaint of pain and swelling in the upper right anterior region that had been present for 8 months. On examination, a diffuse swelling was observed on the right side of the face, and an erythematous growth was found on the right side of the maxilla. Radiographic examination revealed ill-defined radiolucency and significant bone loss on the right side of the maxilla. Destruction of the lower orbital margin was also noted. The patient underwent an incisional biopsy, and the histopathological examination showed the presence of odontogenic epithelium in various patterns, predominantly in a follicular pattern. A diagnosis of AC was established based on the histopathological examination. Immunohistochemistry further confirmed the diagnosis by staining positive for CK19. 

Diagnosis:
Odontogenic tumor - AC

Treatment:
The patient received definitive treatment via a surgical approach. No complications were reported post-surgery. The patient was advised to follow-up regularly for further monitoring.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition at discharge was stable. There were no reported complications, and the surgical intervention was successful. 

Follow-up:
The patient was recommended to schedule routine follow-up appointments for further assessment and monitoring. 

Summary:
The patient, a 52-year-old male, presented with pain and swelling in the upper right anterior region. A diagnosis of odontogenic tumor - AC - was established based on the histopathological examination and immunohistochemistry. The patient received surgical treatment, which was successful without complications. No further complications were reported post-surgery, and the patient's condition at discharge was stable. The patient was advised to schedule routine follow-up appointments for further assessment and monitoring.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 8-year-old female spayed outdoor-only mixed breed dog
Hospitalization Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Reason for Hospitalization:
The patient presented with prerenal azotemia and suspected urinary tract infection, which worsened despite initial treatment. Further evaluation showed a heteroechoic mass arising from the caudal margin of the left liver, splenic nodules, and a single left renal cortical cyst. Aspiration biopsy of the liver mass revealed a population of round cells compatible with a plasma cell neoplasm. The patient was diagnosed with a LC multiple myeloma following additional testing.

Hospital Course:
During hospitalization, the patient's azotemia worsened despite fluid treatment, and a renal diet was initiated. After discharge, the patient underwent a liver lobectomy to remove the solitary liver mass and renal biopsy specimens confirmed chronic tubulointerstitial lymphoplasmacytic nephritis consistent with end-stage renal disease. Hepatic lymph nodes did not show evidence of metastatic disease. Chemotherapy was not pursued. Despite medical intervention, the patient's renal function declined, and the patient was euthanized approximately 5 months after surgical excision.

Diagnoses:
LC multiple myeloma, chronic tubulointerstitial lymphoplasmacytic nephritis consistent with end-stage renal disease

Summary:
The patient presented with prerenal azotemia and suspected urinary tract infection that worsened despite initial treatment. Further evaluation showed a LC multiple myeloma and chronic tubulointerstitial lymphoplasmacytic nephritis consistent with end-stage renal disease. The patient underwent a liver lobectomy to remove the solitary liver mass and renal biopsy specimens were obtained. Despite medical intervention, renal function declined, and the patient was euthanized approximately 5 months after surgical excision.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: RS, 12-year-old female child

Date of Admission: [Date of Admission]

Date of Discharge: [Date of Discharge]

Admission Diagnosis: Dermatitis artefacta

Clinical Course:

RS was brought to the dermatology outpatient department with sudden onset of multiple geometric erythematous lesions with sharp margins on both her arms. There were no complaints of pain or discharge from the lesions. After investigations, the diagnosis was dermatitis artefacta and the child was referred to the psychiatry OPD.

During the consultation with the child and her parents, it was discovered that RS was experiencing difficulty in studying and was often rebuked by her father for her poor academic performance. She talked about the difficulty in focusing on studies since her primary school days and inability to organize her tasks which would often result in late submissions of her work. She also talked about feelings of loneliness and inadequacy due to the lack of attention from her father. The child fulfilled criteria for ADHD, predominantly inattentive type as per DSM-5, and was prescribed with tablet atomoxetine 10 mg. RS has been under regular follow-up and her condition has improved.

Recommendations:

1. Encourage parents to support RS in her academic endeavors.
2. Encourage regular follow-up visits for medication management.
3. Advise RS to practice relaxation techniques to manage stress.
4. Encourage parents to attend parenting classes to learn how to provide constructive support to their children.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 23-year-old primigravida at 13 weeks of gestation, presented with urgency, dysuria, and increased frequency of urine. An examination revealed a mobile hard mass in the right iliac fossa and a large bony mass in the vagina. A probable diagnosis of bladder stone complicating pregnancy was made. She was admitted to the tertiary hospital where an ultrasound confirmed the presence of mild bilateral hydroureteronephrosis and a large vesical calculus measuring 8.3 cm.

Tests and Procedures:

The patient underwent an open cystolithotomy under spinal anesthesia. Intraoperative cystoscopy revealed bladder trabeculation with a stone sitting in the anterior wall of trabeculation. Two small diverticuli were seen. Right ureteric orifice was seen refluxing and pus flakes were present. On cystolithotomy, a 8 x 7 cm stone was removed.

Follow-Up Care:

Postoperatively, the patient had continuous bladder drainage for 2 weeks and was treated with appropriate antibiotics. She also received antibiotic prophylaxis till delivery. She delivered normally a live-term baby girl of Apgar 9 and 10 and birth weight 2.42 kg at 38 weeks of gestation and is on regular follow up and doing well.

Diagnosis:

Bladder stone complicating pregnancy with mild bilateral hydroureteronephrosis.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient was discharged in good condition.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient was advised to continue regular follow-up appointments and to seek medical advice if there are any issues with urination or abdominal pain.

Patient: 9-day-old African-American girl

Reason for admission:
Evaluation of a well-circumscribed, nontender, and firm soft tissue mass on the anterior abdominal wall. The mass was noted at birth but was undetected on prenatal ultrasound evaluations.

Hospital Course:
An initial abdominal ultrasound of the patient on the first day of life revealed a left upper quadrant soft tissue mass and similar subcutaneous nodules on the upper back and left hip. Several diagnostic imaging tests later, an incisional biopsy revealed a fibromyxoid stromal background. Immunohistochemical stains were performed and the tumor stained positive for β-catenin (cytoplasmic only) and smooth muscle actin. Based on these pathology studies and the clinical presentation, the patient was diagnosed with infantile myofibroma (IM). She was then treated with vinblastine and methotrexate chemotherapy that lasted for 9 months. Her condition was stable at 13 months of age when she was last seen. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
Infantile myofibroma (IM)

Discharge Condition: 
Stable

Treatment: 
Vinblastine and methotrexate chemotherapy

Follow-up Plan:
Unknown as the patient has been lost to follow-up. 

Clinical findings:
Left upper quadrant soft tissue mass, similar subcutaneous nodules on the upper back and left hip.

Radiographic Differential Diagnosis:
Metastatic neuroblastoma, infection, multifocal Langerhans cell histiocytosis, IM, neurofibroma.

Final Pathology:
IM with β-catenin (cytoplasmic only) and smooth muscle actin positivity.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with craniosynostosis and syndactyly of the hands and feet. A diagnosis of Apert syndrome (AS) was confirmed after genetic testing revealed a mutation in the FGFR2 gene. No mutations were found in either parent, indicating that the mutation was spontaneous. The patient was treated symptomatically and monitored closely during hospitalization. The patient's symptoms stabilized, and the patient was deemed ready for discharge.

Presenting Symptoms:

Craniosynostosis and syndactyly of the hands and feet.

Diagnosis:

Apert syndrome (AS).

Treatment:

Symptomatic treatment and monitoring.

Hospital Course and Progress:

The patient's symptoms stabilized, and the patient was deemed ready for discharge.

Follow-up Recommendations:

Long-term monitoring is recommended for this patient due to the genetic nature of the condition. Referral to a genetic counselor is advised for the patient and family. Follow-up with a specialist in craniofacial abnormalities is also recommended.

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY:

Patient: 65-70-year-old woman with transient vertigo and ear fullness

Medical History:
- Reported transient vertigo for 6 years
- Breast cancer diagnosis 2 years ago

Clinical Findings:
- Occurrence of vertigo increased to 2-3 times a month after estrogen treatment initiation
- Vertigo lasted for around 30 minutes accompanied by ear fullness and hearing difficulty on the left ear
- Interictal examination showed no spontaneous or triggered nystagmus during positional maneuvers or after horizontal head-shaking
- Fluctuating left sensorineural hearing loss, especially in the lower frequency range
- Results of bithermal caloric tests, cervical and ocular VEMPs, and brain MRIs and MR angiography were normal

Diagnosis:
- Meniere's disease (MD)

Treatment:
- Medication including 12 mg of betahistine, 25/25 mg of spironolactone/hydrochlorothiazide per day
- Vertigo spell markedly decreased with medication

Plan:
- Recommend patient to continue medication regimen and follow-up with physician for any further concerns or changes in symptoms.

Admission and Clinical Course:
The patient was a 69-year-old female with multiple comorbidities, including diabetes, hypertension, and dyslipidemia, who underwent bifrontal craniotomy in 1996 complicated by osteomyelitis. Despite several courses of combination antibiotics, the wound continued to be foul-smelling. The patient presented with counting finger vision and mature cataract bilaterally. Funduscopy was negative for diabetic retinopathy. Sequential sutureless phacoemulsification was performed, with final uncorrected vision of 6/7.5 in each eye, 5 months apart.

Hospital Course:
Surgery was carried out under topical anesthesia and without the application of topical povidone iodine. The eyelid and eyebrow region were scrubbed with povidone iodine, and self-sealing limbal tracts were created while avoiding multiple entry and exit from the eyes. Special attention was paid to keeping the eye at a pressure of 25 mmHg throughout the procedure. No intracameral antibiotics were given at the end of surgery. Postoperatively, the patient received tobramycin and dexamethasone ointment and drops of moxifloxacin along with a combination of netilmicin sulfate with dexamethasone phosphate for 3 weeks, followed by 5 days of oral moxifloxacin. The patient was closely monitored every 2 days and showed no signs of anterior chamber inflammation for 2 months postoperatively.

Diagnosis:
Counting finger vision with mature cataract bilaterally.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Instructions/Follow-up:
No instructions or follow-up indicated.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with progressively worsening epigastric and back pain, along with a 12 kg weight loss and jaundice. Liver function tests showed evidence of biliary obstruction. Imaging studies revealed the presence of a pancreatic mass and peripancreatic lymphadenopathy, without involvement of mesenteric vessels or liver.

The patient underwent ERCP and insertion of a biliary stent which provided relief from the obstruction. Biliary brushings and subsequent FNA were not diagnostic. Laparotomy and open biopsy of the peripancreatic lymph nodes revealed diffuse large B-cell lymphoma which was CD20 positive. Resection was not performed.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with three cycles of CHOP chemotherapy followed by involved field radiotherapy (42 Gy in 19 fractions). He had a complete response to treatment.

Relapse and Further Treatment:
The patient relapsed out of field 21 months following diagnosis, 17 months after treatment. He received complete response after being treated with second-line ICE chemotherapy, high-dose BEAM chemotherapy and autologous stem cell transplantation. After 64 months following diagnosis, 37 months from 2nd treatment, the patient remains in remission.

Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Pancreatic mass with peripancreatic lymphadenopathy
2. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, CD20 positive

Discharge Instructions:
1. Follow up with oncologist as scheduled
2. Take all prescribed medications as directed
3. Adhere to a healthy diet and exercise regimen
4. Report any unusual symptoms immediately

Follow-Up Plan:
The patient will continue to be followed by an oncologist on a regular basis to monitor his condition and response to treatment.

Signed,
[REDACTED], MD

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Name]
MR#: [Number]
Age: 75
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted due to hip prosthesis loosening 18 months after a hip revision surgery for P. avidum infection. Aspiration from the hip showed growth of P. avidum, and a CT scan revealed abscess formation below the acetabular floor inside the pelvis. The hip prosthesis was extracted in a two-stage hip revision surgery approach, and treatment was initiated with piperacillin/tazobactam. After 8 days, treatment was changed to benzyl-penicillin. Three weeks later, the patient experienced increased hip pain, and a CT scan showed multiple abscesses around the Girdlestone hip. Another reoperation was performed with debridement, locally administered gentamicin, and drainage. Treatment was initiated with piperacillin/tazobactam and vancomycin before being switched to trimethoprim/sulphamethoxazole orally. The patient was discharged 6 weeks later with minor pain from the hip, and treatment with trimethoprim/sulphamethoxazole and amoxicillin orally for 6 months. After treatment, the patient’s CRP was normal, and the second-stage surgery was performed 10 months after the first-stage revision, where there were no growths.

Diagnosis:
Hip prosthesis loosening due to P. avidum infection.

Treatment:
The patient received a two-stage hip revision surgery approach with debridement, locally administered gentamicin, and drainage. Treatment was initiated with piperacillin/tazobactam before being switched to benzyl-penicillin and later trimethoprim/sulphamethoxazole orally. Treatment with trimethoprim/sulphamethoxazole and amoxicillin orally for 6 months followed the second-stage revision surgery.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient experienced minor hip pain.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient is discharged and will follow-up with their medical team for further assistance.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient was a 7-year-old male child who presented to the Department of Pediatric Dentistry with a history of swelling in the lower right anterior segment for the past 6 months. Intraoral examination revealed a hard, non-tender swelling on the alveolar ridge distal to the right mandibular lateral incisor. Radiographic examination revealed a well-demarcated radiopaque lesion associated with missing deciduous canine. Based on these findings, a provisional diagnosis of complex odontoma was made.

The patient underwent surgical removal of the lesion with an incision given extending from the midbuccal aspect of 41 to the midbuccal aspect of 84. After full-thickness mucoperiosteal flap was raised, superficial bone was removed followed by the removal of the mass of ill-formed calcified structure along with the impacted deciduous canine, with elevator without damage to adjacent teeth. The flap was approximated and sutured. The histopathological examination of the decalcified hard tissue mass revealed an ill-organized structure of enamel, dentin, cementum, and pulp tissue, with larger quantities of dentin and cementum, suggestive of complex odontoma.

Based on the histopathological examination and appearance of the gross specimen, it was confirmed that the patient had complex odontoma, which is a rare entity in a young child. Appropriate postoperative care was given, and the patient was discharged in a stable condition.

Follow-up appointments were advised to ensure proper healing of the surgical site and monitoring of the patient's condition. The patient was advised to maintain good oral hygiene habits to prevent future complications.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 68 years
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted with a diagnosis of center-involved diabetic macular edema (DME) in the right and left eyes, which was unresponsive to prior intravitreal injection (IVI) therapies and macular and peripheral laser treatments. Additionally, she had comorbidities of hypertension and dyslipidemia.

The patient underwent a pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) with internal limiting membrane (ILM) peeling combined with phacoemulsification in the left eye in November 2014, followed by an intravitreal injection of IVTA with no regression of the DME. Due to the unresponsiveness to IVTA, a change of therapy to a FAc implant was considered in mid-2015, which was injected into both the right and left eyes.

Throughout the patient's hospitalization, eye specialists monitored her condition and adjusted her medications as necessary. The patient's condition improved following the FAc implant therapy, and her discharge on [REDACTED] was approved by the treating physician.

The patient is advised to follow up with her eye specialists for further assessment and continued care.

Primary Diagnosis:
- Center-involved DME in the right and left eye

Comorbidities:
- Hypertension
- Dyslipidemia

Treatment:
- PPV with ILM peeling combined with phacoemulsification in the left eye
- Intravitreal injection of IVTA
- FAc implant therapy in both eyes

Follow-up Plan:
- Follow up with eye specialists for further assessment and continued care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 29-year-old female

Chief Complaint: Visual loss in the right eye

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with visual loss in her right eye and was found to have keratic precipitates, anterior chamber cells, and anterior vitreous cells. A fundus examination showed vitritis and a focal necrotizing retinal choroidal lesion. A SS-OCT image obtained through the active lesion showed nerve fiber swelling and choroidal thickening. The OCTA performed on the lesion showed reduced blood flow. The patient was diagnosed with toxoplasmosis based on positive IgG levels and was treated with a combination of trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole, as well as prednisone. Lesion regression and visual acuity improvement were seen. After healing, SS-OCT imaging of the lesion showed disorganization of the entire retinal architecture. The borders of the retinal layers in the retinal choroidal lesion were unrecognizable. The choroid surrounding the lesion site was thinner compared to the adjacent areas. An OCTA image of the lesion showed increase in flow signal and anomalous vessels in the retinochoroiditis area.

Hospital Course Summary:
A 29-year-old female presented with visual loss in her right eye. She was found to have keratic precipitates, cells in the anterior chamber and vitreous, and a focal necrotizing retinal choroidal lesion. A diagnosis of toxoplasmosis was confirmed by positive IgG levels and treated with a combination of trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole, as well as prednisone. The patient's lesion regression and visual acuity improved after treatment. After healing, imaging showed disorganization of the entire retinal architecture and thinner choroid surrounding the lesion site. Further imaging also showed an increase in blood flow and anomalous vessels in the retinochoroiditis area.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]
Date of Admission: October 19, 2009
Date of Discharge: [Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with a clinical diagnosis of acute appendicitis and underwent emergency surgery. Pathology report indicated a dilated appendix with the presence of multiple whitish opaque globules in the lumen ranging from 0.2 to 0.7 cm in diameter. A ruptured diverticulum was identified near the distal portion along with several smaller non-ruptured diverticula. The entire appendix was evaluated histologically, which revealed hyperplasia of the appendiceal mucosa, slight gland serration, and increased mucin-producing cells at the upper half of the mucosa. Due to acute inflammation, the diagnosis of Low-Grade Appendiceal Mucinous Neoplasm (LAMN), Low Risk of Recurrence, was excluded.

Clinical Findings:
Based on the pathology report, the diagnosis of acellular extra-appendiceal mucin was determined. The periappendiceal mucin did not contain any epithelial elements, and thus, the diagnosis of LAMN was ruled out. As molecular testing was not performed, the patient was advised to undergo follow-up to exclude recurrence with mucinous ascites.

Treatment:
The patient underwent an emergency surgery for acute appendicitis, and the pathology report revealed acellular extra-appendiceal mucin. No further treatment was recommended, and the patient was advised to return for a follow-up screening to exclude recurrence.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions to return for a follow-up screening.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to undergo follow-up to exclude recurrence with mucinous ascites.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 21-year-old primigravida who presented at 38 weeks gestation for elective cesarean section due to fetal anomalies. A spinal anesthetic was performed without complications and a viable infant was delivered. Approximately 40 minutes after the intrathecal injection, the patient experienced right sided peri-oral numbness, dysphagia and dysarthria. Shortly thereafter, she developed a constellation of neurologic symptoms including horizontal nystagmus of the right eye, right sided ptosis with facial droop, and right upper extremity weakness with a “claw hand”. Vital signs and mentation remained normal, and the patient's symptoms resolved within 120 minutes.

Clinical Findings:
A non-contrast computed tomography of the head showed no intracranial pathology. A brain magnetic resonance imaging and a magnetic resonance angiography of the neck vessels were negative. An echocardiogram with agitated saline bubble study showed no right-to-left shunt.

Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's clinical presentation, the differential diagnosis for her neurologic symptoms consisted of high spinal, stroke or transient ischemic attack, air embolus, amniotic fluid embolus, and seizure. However, no definitive diagnosis was reached.

Disposition and Follow-up:
The patient was discharged after her symptoms fully resolved and at this time, no follow-up care is needed. She was advised to seek immediate medical attention for recurrence of any of the symptoms that she experienced.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 28-year-old male with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections and a previous cystolithotomy, presented to the surgical emergency department with pus discharge per urethra. Upon examination, ultrasound revealed an echogenic mass in the urinary bladder, and a later CT scan confirmed that it was multiple vesical calculi and a diffusely thickened wall of the right lateral wall of the urinary bladder. A cystoscopy revealed a retained gauze piece with organized pus flakes adhering to the anterior wall of the urinary bladder. The patient underwent exploration of the urinary bladder, during which the gauze piece was successfully removed, and the rest of the bladder wall was found to be normal. Appropriate antibiotics were started for Klebsiella spp. infection. The patient was discharged on the 4th day post-operation. Follow-up for 8 months was unremarkable, and the patient remained asymptomatic and free from recurrent UTI.

Hospital Course:

Upon examination, ultrasound revealed an echogenic mass in the urinary bladder, and a later CT scan confirmed that it was multiple vesical calculi and a diffusely thickened wall of the right lateral wall of the urinary bladder. The patient underwent exploration of the urinary bladder, during which the gauze piece was successfully removed, and the rest of the bladder wall was found to be normal. Appropriate antibiotics were started for Klebsiella spp. infection. The patient has not yet been discharged and remains under observation.

Discharge Summary:

Patient 2 is a 64-year-old male who presented to the physical medicine and rehabilitation department with spasticity. The patient had undergone anterior approach microscopic discectomy on C5–6 and C5–6 with an interbody fusion and a decompressive total laminectomy on C4–6 using a posterior approach and lateral mass screw fixation. The procedure was performed due to cervical spondylotic myelopathy with spinal stenosis on C4–6 and had resulted in significant improvement of pain and motor weakness. However, the patient had developed right ankle clonus and right plantar flexor spasticity one month after the operation. The patient was treated with PRF procedure on the right S1 DRG, 5 Hz and 5 ms pulsed width for 360 seconds at 45 V, which resulted in complete resolution of ankle clonus and reduced MAS score from 2 to 1. The patient reported no complications after the procedure.

At 6 months post PRF procedure, the ankle clonus recurrence was observed, but only occasionally with a degree of 1-2 beats. Due to minor complaints from the patient, the decision was made to observe the symptoms without any further intervention.

Overall, the patient made significant improvement following the procedure, resulting in complete resolution of ankle clonus and reduced spasticity.

Discharge Summary

The patient presented to the emergency department with left gaze preference and right-side hemiparesis. CT angiography revealed a distal left M1 middle cerebral artery occlusion. The patient underwent endovascular mechanical embolectomy via direct left common carotid artery puncture.

The patient underwent endovascular mechanical embolectomy with a stentreiver device and aspiration catheter.

The patient recovered remarkably well and was discharged from the hospital with a three-month modified Rankin score of 1.

Left M1 middle cerebral artery occlusion.

Following a CT angiography, the patient underwent endovascular mechanical embolectomy via direct left common carotid artery puncture. The patient recovered well and was discharged with a three-month modified Rankin score of 1.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not specified
Age: 20-year-old 
Gender: Male
Diagnosis: Cap Polyposis 
Treatment: H. pylori eradication therapy and en bloc excision of the polyps with ESD

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 20-year-old Japanese man, presented with a 1-year history of hematochezia and tenesmus. Laboratory tests showed mild hypoproteinemia, but no other abnormalities. Colonoscopy revealed cap polyposis, and magnification endoscopy with narrow-band imaging showed exudate in the white caps overlying long branching tortuous crypts in the basal part of the polyps. EUS showed mucosal thickening without evidence of invasion into the submucosa, and histologic findings from a polyp revealed elongated, tortuous, branched crypts lined with hyperplastic epithelium with inflammatory cell infiltration and a mild degree of fibromusculosis in the lamina propria. 

Computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging showed multiple elevated lesions thickening the walls of the sigmoid colon and rectum. The patient had no evidence of H. pylori infection, but owing to previous evidence that H. pylori eradication therapy was effective for patients with cap polyposis, H. pylori eradication therapy with vonoprazan, amoxicillin, and clarithromycin was initiated. However, abdominal symptoms, bowel habits, and endoscopic findings did not improve over the six months after therapy. Therefore, en bloc excision of the polyps with ESD was performed, and after resection, the patient's symptoms disappeared, and he had no endoscopic evidence of recurrence for six months.

Summary:
A 20-year-old Japanese man presented with a 1-year history of hematochezia and tenesmus. He was diagnosed with cap polyposis based on endoscopic and histopathological characteristics. H. pylori eradication therapy and en bloc excision of the polyps with ESD were the treatments provided. The patient's symptoms disappeared, and he had no endoscopic evidence of recurrence for six months.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient was admitted for multiple warty lesions with severe pruritus on the lower legs and dorsa of feet. The lesions had been present for one year and did not respond to topical treatments. Physical examination revealed well defined hyperpigmented verrucous plaques with follicular prominence of varying sizes. Follicular prominence and visible wickham's striae were not apparent. Based on these findings, the provisional diagnosis of hypertrophic lichen planus was made.

Systemic examination revealed no abnormalities. Routine hematological and biochemical investigations were normal. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of hypertrophic lichen planus characterized by hyperkeratotic, acanthotic squamous epithelium with elongation of the rete ridges and dense bands of lymphohistocytic infiltration in papillary dermis hugging the epidermis. 

Patient was treated with [REDACTED] and observed for [REDACTED]. She experienced no complications or adverse effects during her stay. Patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions for wound care and follow-up visits with her [REDACTED]. 

In summary, patient presented with multiple warty lesions on the lower legs and dorsa of feet with severe pruritus. Diagnosis of hypertrophic lichen planus was confirmed through histopathological examination. Patient was managed with [REDACTED] and discharged with instructions for wound care and follow-up visits.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 23-year-old male with no known comorbidities, presented with complaints of epigastric pain and frequent bilious vomiting. He was evaluated clinically and with ultrasound and magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography. The imaging studies revealed a hypoechoic lesion located around the porta hepatis with a contracted gall bladder and no intra-hepatic biliary radicle dilatation. The patient was diagnosed with a Type II choledochal cyst/double GB/Type VI choledochal cyst, and a diagnostic laparoscopy with cholecystectomy +/- common bile duct excision with hepaticojejunostomy was planned.

Discharge Summary:
The patient underwent a diagnostic laparoscopy with cholecystectomy alone due to the absence of communication between the cyst and the common bile duct. The post-operative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged in stable condition on Day 3 after surgery. The gross specimen revealed a contracted gall bladder with an isolated mass attached to the anterolateral wall of the cystic duct. Microscopy showed papillary hyperplasia of the mucosa with features of chronic inflammation in the wall of the gall bladder. The patient was advised to follow up with his primary care provider in 2 weeks.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital Course: 
The patient, a 2-year-old male child, was admitted to our emergency clinic after a tractor crash accident. The right wheel of the tractor had passed over the child's thorax. Emergency diagnostic procedures were performed including abdominal and thoracic ultrasonography and thoracic computed tomography (CT) scan. Bilateral minimal pneumothorax and severe parenchymal contusion at the right lung were found on the CT scan. The patient was diagnosed with retroperitoneal DR and was monitored in the hospital for 1 week. The patient did not require surgical intervention, and all subsequent diagnostic procedures revealed no further complications. The patient was discharged from the hospital without any reported complications.

Hospital Course Summary:
Upon admission, the patient underwent standard emergency diagnostic procedures, revealing bilateral minimal pneumothorax, severe parenchymal contusion at the right lung, and retroperitoneal DR. The patient was diagnosed with the aforementioned conditions and was closely monitored for a week. The patient did not require surgical intervention, and further diagnostic procedures revealed no further complications. The patient was discharged without any reported complications.

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient presented to the emergency ward with acute onset weakness in all four limbs. Laboratory findings revealed hyperthyroid status-Graves' disease, manifested by high free T3 and T4 with low TSH in serum, and thyroid peroxidase (TPO) antibody. The patient was diagnosed with thyrotoxic hypokalemic periodic paralysis (THPP) due to Grave's disease and was treated with intravenous (IV) potassium chloride and magnesium sulfate supplemented with cautious monitoring and supportive management. The patient's quadriparesis improved after K+ value returned to normal.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

Graves' disease, thyrotoxic hypokalemic periodic paralysis (THPP).

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

1. Follow up with your primary care physician or an endocrinologist within the next 2 weeks.
2. Take medications as prescribed by your physician.
3. Strictly follow dietary restrictions especially avoiding foods high in iodine.
4. Rest and avoid strenuous activities until advised by your physician.
5. Monitor any symptoms or signs of hyperthyroidism or thyrotoxic hypokalemic periodic paralysis carefully and report any concerns to your physician immediately.
6. Keep all follow-up appointments and laboratory tests scheduled by the physician.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Admission Date: Jan 13, 2016
Discharge Date: Jan 27, 2016
Hospital: [Hospital Name]

IDENTIFYING INFORMATION:
The patient is a 23-year-old female who presented to [Hospital Name] with the desire for esthetic facial contouring surgery due to a complaint of a long and flat face. She had previously received orthodontic treatment for protruding lips at a local clinic.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
Upon admission, imaging and consultations were conducted to determine the most effective surgical plan. Given the patient's condition, a custom-made silicone implant for frontal augmentation was fabricated. The surgery involved a narrowing genioplasty and reduction and rotational malarplasty, followed by frontal augmentation using the silicone implant.

The patient experienced discomfort and swelling during her hospital stay, which required surgical intervention to remove a hematoma around the coronal incision area. Additional antibiotics and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications were prescribed to manage these symptoms.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
The patient's diagnosis was based on her complaint of physical appearance and the final surgical procedures that took place. There were no other significant diagnoses during her hospital stay.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient was prescribed a regimen of pain medication and instructed to rest comfortably at home. Additionally, she was advised to avoid strenuous activity and to refrain from touching or manipulating her surgical incisions. The patient's surgical staples were removed during her follow-up visit per standard protocol.

FOLLOW-UP CARE:
The patient was scheduled for a follow-up visit with her surgical team six months after her initial surgery.

Discharge Summary:

This is a summary of the hospitalization course and post-operative care for a 57-year-old man who was diagnosed with mixed adeno-neuroendocrine carcinoma (MANEC) in the ampulla of Vater. The patient's condition was complicated by jaundice and dark urine. He was evaluated with imaging studies that showed a lesion in the duodenal ampullary region. The patient underwent a pancreaticoduodenectomy, following which the adenocarcinoma and small cell NEC components were identified in the resected specimen.

During the hospitalization, the patient's serum bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, and aminotransferase levels were elevated. The patient had no significant comorbidities or previous surgeries and was medically stable throughout the hospitalization period. The patient was managed by a multidisciplinary team and received appropriate medical care, including surgical intervention, imaging studies, and laboratory tests. The patient was discharged with a follow-up appointment scheduled with the treating consultant.

In summary, the patient was diagnosed with MANEC in the ampulla of Vater and underwent a pancreaticoduodenectomy. The postoperative course was uncomplicated, and the patient was discharged in stable condition, with instructions for follow-up appointments with the treating physicians.

Hospital Course:

This 28-year-old woman presented with hip and gluteal pain along with morning stiffness lasting 1 hour, after starting a daily dose of isotretinoin for acne vulgaris. On physical examination, the patient had a decreased lumbar range of motion, and the FABER test was positive on the right side. CRP and ESR were within the normal range, and the patient was negative for HLA B27. MRI revealed bilateral bone marrow edema in the sacral and iliac wings of both sacroiliac joints consistent with active sacroiliitis.

Treatment and Management:

The patient was started on NSAIDs and the isotretinoin treatment was discontinued. Her complaints resolved after 1 year and did not recur. On control MRI after 2 years, regression in the bone marrow edema of the sacroiliac joint was observed.

Follow-up:

The patient was discharged with instructions for continued NSAIDs therapy and follow-up with her primary care physician. She was also advised to undergo regular follow-up for monitoring of her condition.

Clinical Diagnosis:

Acute sacroiliitis with bone marrow edema in the sacral and iliac wings of the sacroiliac joints, likely related to isotretinoin therapy for acne vulgaris.

Prognosis:

The patient responded well to the discontinuation of isotretinoin therapy and NSAIDs treatment. There was a regression in the bone marrow edema on control MRI after 2 years, indicating a positive prognosis for the patient.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 56-year-old woman with arterial hypertension

Hospital course:
The patient underwent carpal tunnel release surgery under general anesthesia without difficulty. However, during extubation, the patient coughed vigorously and made a violent neck movement, which resulted in a tracheal laceration. The patient was diagnosed with pneumomediastinum and subcutaneous emphysema. She was transferred to the intensive care unit and received a course of broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics. A 7.5 mm ID cuffed endotracheal tube was placed as close to the lesion as possible near the carina, and low-tidal-volume lung ventilation and pressure-controlled mode were applied to allow the lesion to recover without deteriorating the pneumomediastinum. After three days, the patient showed marked improvement, and after eight days, the lesion was healing. Endotracheal tube extubation was performed 13 days after the initial injury, and the patient was discharged in good condition 5 days later.

Diagnosis:
Tracheal laceration, pneumomediastinum, and subcutaneous emphysema

Treatment:
Low-tidal-volume lung ventilation with pressure-controlled mode, course of broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics, and replacement of the endotracheal tube as close to the lesion as possible near the carina

Outcome:
The patient showed marked improvement and was discharged in good condition.

Hospital Course

The 21-year-old female patient was admitted with a history of progressive enlargement of her right distal arm and digits since birth. There was no reported history of neurovascular symptoms or pain. She underwent a physical examination that revealed a soft-tissue mass on the volar aspect of her enlarged thumb and disfigurement of her digits and distal arm. Imaging and cytological findings suggested the possibility of Madelung's lipomatosis. The patient underwent a debulking surgery that confirmed the diagnosis. She was stable post-surgery and was subsequently discharged.

The patient was admitted with an enlarged right distal arm and digits with a soft-tissue mass on the volar aspect of her enlarged thumb. Imaging and cytological findings suggested Madelung's lipomatosis, and a debulking surgery confirmed the diagnosis. The patient was stable post-surgery with no reported complications.

Instructions were given to the patient to follow up with her primary care physician for further management. The patient was advised to avoid any physical activity that may worsen her condition and to monitor her symptoms. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Follow-up with the multidisciplinary team is recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: NP, 60-year-old, Female

Admission Date: N/A (Case Report)

Discharge Date: N/A (Case Report)

Medical History: Hypertension

Hospital Course:

NP presented with a three-hour history of the inability to close the mouth after yawning. She had a similar incident four (4) months earlier. The patient did not have any previous traumatic history.

Diagnosis:

Upon evaluation, the diagnosis of bilateral anterior temporomandibular joint (TMJ) dislocation was confirmed. The patient's condition improved after the successful treatment using the extra-oral technique.

Treatment:

The Hippocrates maneuver was not successful, and the patient underwent a successful extra-oral procedure. After the treatment, the patient was kept immobilized with the barrel bandage.

Outcome:

NP was discharged in a stable condition and advised to follow-up with her healthcare provider as needed.

Follow-Up:

The patient is advised to follow-up with her regular healthcare provider for any further management of the underlying condition.

Instructions:

The patient is advised to avoid any activities that may cause a similar incident. In case of any symptoms or discomfort, the patient is advised to seek medical attention immediately.

Summary:

NP, a 60-year-old female, was diagnosed with bilateral anterior temporomandibular joint (TMJ) dislocation. She underwent a successful extra-oral procedure, and after immobilization with the barrel bandage, the patient was discharged in a stable condition. She has been advised to follow-up with her regular healthcare provider as needed and avoid any activities that may cause a similar incident.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 6-year-old girl, was admitted to Booali Sina Hospital in Sari, northern Iran with vulvar bleeding and dizziness. She had been experiencing the symptoms for one week prior to admission. The patient denied any history of trauma and did not complain of any other symptoms. The parents revealed that the patient had been swimming in a pond for about one hour before the onset of symptoms.

Physical Examination:
Clinical examination revealed a leech about 5 cm in length attached to the minor labia of the vulva. No abnormality or trauma was seen, and the hymen was intact. The leech was removed using forceps, and the vulva and vaginal cavity were washed twice with normal saline and antibacterial solutions. The bleeding stopped 1 hour later.

Treatment:
To improve the symptoms associated with vulvar bleeding, the leech was removed and the affected area was cleaned with normal saline and antibacterial solutions. The patient was discharged the following day.

Follow-Up:
The patient was followed up 2 days after the removal of the leech and showed no symptoms of infestation or bleeding.

Conclusion:
A leech belonging to the Erpobdellidae family was found attached to the minor labia of the vulva. It was successfully removed, and the patient showed no symptoms of infestation or bleeding upon follow-up.
